title: Priestly Garments
shortSummary: Exodus 28 details God's instructions to Moses for making the sacred garments for Aaron and his sons, who are to serve as priests. These garments symbolize holiness, beauty, and the responsibility of representing Israel before the Lord. The chapter emphasizes the importance of consecration and the divine provision for worship.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Moses' brother and the first high priest, chosen to minister before the LORD wearing the holy garments.

keyCharacters.name: Nadab and Abihu
keyCharacters.description: Sons of Aaron who are included in the priestly ministry and consecration.

keyCharacters.name: Eleazar and Ithamar
keyCharacters.description: Younger sons of Aaron who also serve as priests alongside their father.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: God's appointed leader who receives and executes the instructions for making the priestly garments.

definitions.definition: A sacred garment worn by the high priest, made of fine linen and embroidered with gold, blue, purple, and scarlet threads.
A square, double-layered piece of cloth set with twelve precious stones representing the twelve tribes of Israel, worn by the high priest over the ephod.
Objects placed in the breastplate used by the high priest to discern the will of God in judgment.
The turban or headpiece worn by the high priest, upon which was placed a gold plate inscribed 'HOLINESS TO THE LORD.'
The consecrated clothing worn by priests symbolizing their set-apart role to minister before God.

outline.heading: Appointment of Aaron and His Sons as Priests
outline.description: God commands Moses to take Aaron and his sons from Israel to serve as priests and instructs the making of holy garments for glory and beauty, signifying their sacred role.

outline.heading: The Ephod and Shoulder Stones
outline.description: Detailed instructions are given for making the ephod, including the use of gold and colored threads, and the engraving of the twelve tribes' names on onyx stones set on the shoulders as a memorial.

outline.heading: The Breastplate of Judgment
outline.description: The breastplate is described with its twelve precious stones representing the tribes of Israel, the attachment to the ephod, and the inclusion of the Urim and Thummim for divine judgment.

outline.heading: The Robe, Mitre, and Consecration
outline.description: Instructions for the blue robe with pomegranates and golden bells, the golden plate on the mitre inscribed 'HOLINESS TO THE LORD,' and the making of linen garments for Aaron and his sons, culminating in their anointing and consecration.

application: Recognize the importance of holiness and reverence in approaching God, reflecting on how our lives and attitudes should be set apart for His service.
Understand the significance of spiritual leadership and the responsibility to represent God's people faithfully before Him.
Value the role of consecration and obedience in ministry, committing ourselves to God's calling with dedication and purity.
Apply the principle of bearing others before the Lord in prayer, just as Aaron bore the names of Israel on his garments.

keyVerses.text: And thou shalt make holy garments for Aaron thy brother for glory and for beauty.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the divine purpose behind the priestly garmentsâ€”to reflect God's glory and beauty in worship.

keyVerses.text: And Aaron shall bear the names of the children of Israel in the breastplate of judgment upon his heart, when he goeth in unto the holy place, for a memorial before the LORD continually.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the priest's role to carry the people before God continually, symbolizing intercession and responsibility.

keyVerses.text: And thou shalt make a plate of pure gold, and grave upon it, like the engravings of a signet, HOLINESS TO THE LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse declares the essential holiness required in approaching God and serving Him.

keyVerses.text: And they shall be upon Aaron, and upon his sons, when they come in unto the tabernacle of the congregation, or when they come near unto the altar to minister in the holy place; that they bear not iniquity, and die: it shall be a statute for ever unto him and his seed after him.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the necessity of obedience and consecration for those who serve God, with eternal implications for the priesthood.
